description: From Middle English pastre, pastri, from pastree (variant of pasterie, from Old French pastaierie and Medieval Latin pasteria) or paste + -ri (modern paste +‎ -ry).

entries.meaning: (countable) A baked food item  made from flour and fat pastes such as pie crust; also tarts, bear claws, napoleons, puff pastries, etc.
examples: That pastry shop sells not just pastries, but all kinds of baked goods.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) The food group formed by the various kinds of pastries.
examples: That pastry shop sells not just pastry, but all kinds of baked goods.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) The type of light flour-based dough used in pastries.
(countable, obsolete) A place where pastry is made.
(uncountable) The act or art of making pastry.
examples: He learned pastry from the great Gaston Lenôtre.

entries.meaning: (uncountable, culinary industry) Desserts of all kinds, whether or not these incorporate the baked item made from flour and fat, or that section of a kitchen that prepares these.
examples: I used to work in the fish section, but now I've been moved to pastry.
